com.pb.sawdust.tabledata.basic

Class RowDataTable

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.pb.sawdust.tabledata.AbstractDataTable
      • com.pb.sawdust.tabledata.basic.RowDataTable
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    DataTable, java.lang.Iterable<DataRow>

    public class RowDataTable
extends AbstractDataTable
    The RowDataTable class provides a "row-based" implementation of the DataTable interface. This means that this implementation is optimized for row-wise operations (addRow(Object[]), getData(int), etc.), with the tradeoff being that other operations, in particular column-wise ones, will be less efficient. The actual table data is internally held by this class as java arrays. This class includes a constructor taking a DataTable instance as its sole argument, and can be used when optimized row-wise operations are desired.

      • RowDataTable

        public RowDataTable(TableSchema schema,
            java.lang.Object[][] data)
        Constructor specifying the table structure, as well as data to fill the table with. The data should be organized as required by the addDataByRow(Object[][]) method - its first dimension is the row, and second dimension the column entries.
        Parameters:
        schema - The table's structure.
        data - The data to fill the table with. The first dimension is rows, and the second is columns.

    • Method Detail

      • addColumnToData

        protected <A> boolean addColumnToData(java.lang.String columnLabel,
                          A columnDataArray,
                          DataType type)
        Description copied from class: AbstractDataTable
        Add a column to this data table. This method's specification is identical to com.pb.sawdust.tabledata.DataTable#addColumn(String, Object, DataType), except that it should not check to ensure that columnDataArray is an array nor update the table schema. That is, this class' implementation of the above specified method already carries out those tasks, leaving the user to implement this method, which only adds the column to the data table. This method is optional and need not be implemented (with anything more than a shell method), though in such a case, the com.pb.sawdust.tabledata.DataTable#addColumn(String, Object, DataType) should be overridden to throw an UnsupportedOperationException.
        Specified by:
        addColumnToData in class AbstractDataTable
        Parameters:
        columnLabel - The label for the new column.
        columnDataArray - The new column data for the existing rows in the data table. This must be a java array (this is generified to allow for primitive and object arrays), with one entry for each row, matching the current row ordering of the data table.
        type - The data type of the new column.
        Returns:
        true if the column was added successfully, false otherwise.
        See Also:
        DataTable.addColumn(String, Object, DataType)

      • addRow

        protected boolean addRow(int nextRowIndex,
             java.lang.Object... rowData)
        Description copied from class: AbstractDataTable
        Add a row of data to this data table, with the next row index specified. Specifying the next row index explicitly, as opposed to calling getRowCount() internally, allows for efficiency gains in some instances (such as when using addDataByRow(Object[][])). This method is intended to replace (or wrap) the various addRow methods in the DataTable interface. This method is optional, and it need not be implemented (with anything more than a shell method), though in such a case, the addRow methods should be overridden to throw an UnsupportedOperationException.
        Specified by:
        addRow in class AbstractDataTable
        Parameters:
        nextRowIndex - The next row index in the data table. This value will be identical to a call to getRowCount().
        rowData - The row to add. Consistency checking (column names, types, etc. between row and this data table) may not be performed.
        Returns:
        true if the row was added successfully, false otherwise.

      • addDataByRow

        public boolean addDataByRow(java.lang.Object[][] data)
        Description copied from class: AbstractDataTable
        Add row-based data to this data table Row-based means the data is organized first into a series of rows, and then into a series of column entries. This method is optional, and need not be implemented. If data coersion is enabled then this data will be coerced in place. To change this behavior, override the AbstractDataTable.coerceRowData(Object...) method.
        Specified by:
        addDataByRow in interface DataTable
        Overrides:
        addDataByRow in class AbstractDataTable
        Parameters:
        data - An array of row-based data to add to this data table. Its first dimension is the row, and second dimension the column entries. Each row array must have a length equal to the number of columns in this data table.
        Returns:
        true if the data was added successfully, false otherwise.

      • addDataByColumn

        public boolean addDataByColumn(java.lang.Object[] data)
        Description copied from interface: DataTable
        Add column-based data to this data table. Column-based means the data is organized first into a series of columns, and then into a series of row entries. Each Object in data is to be an array, corresponding to a column in the data set, and whose component type is determined by the respective column data type. This method should allow both object and primitive arrays, so long as they match the column's data type's corresponding object/primitive class. This method is optional, and need not be implemented.
        Specified by:
        addDataByColumn in interface DataTable
        Overrides:
        addDataByColumn in class AbstractDataTable
        Parameters:
        data - An array of arrays holding the new data by columns.
        Returns:
        true if the data was added successfully, false otherwise.

                            int columnIndex)
        Description copied from class: AbstractDataTable
        Get a cell in this data table. Note for implementors: all other getCellValue/getCellValueByKey methods will reflect back and use this method. Thus, if overriding, only this method need be replaced.

        Overrides:

        Parameters:
        rowIndex - The (0-based) index of the row containing the cell.
        columnIndex - The (0-based) index of the column containing the cell.
        Returns:
        the cell value corresponding to rowIndex and columnIndex.

      • setCellValueInData

        protected boolean setCellValueInData(int rowNumber,
                         int columnIndex,
                         java.lang.Object value)
        Description copied from class: AbstractDataTable
        Set the value of a cell in this table. This method should not check the row and column number parameters for validity, but it should throw an exception if the value does not match the column's specified data type. This method is optional, and it need not be implemented (with anything more than a shell method), though in such a case, the setCellValue, setRowData, and setColumnData methods should be overridden to throw an UnsupportedOperationException (or to be implemented to not use this method).
        Specified by:
        setCellValueInData in class AbstractDataTable
        Parameters:
        rowNumber - The (0-based) row number of the cell to be changed.
        columnIndex - The (0-based) column index of the cell to be changed.
        value - The value to set in the cell.
        Returns:
        true if the cell was updated successfully, false otherwise.

      • setRowData

        public boolean setRowData(int rowNumber,
                 java.lang.Object... values)
        Description copied from class: AbstractDataTable
        Set the data in the specified row. A variety of input and data checking is performed, however, no checks are made to ensure the the uniqueness of keys on the table are maintained. This method is optional, and need not be implemented. If data coersion is enabled then this data will be coerced in place. To change this behavior, override the AbstractDataTable.coerceRowData(Object...) method.
        Specified by:
        setRowData in interface DataTable
        Overrides:
        setRowData in class AbstractDataTable
        Parameters:
        rowNumber - The row whose data will be set.
        values - The new row values, their order (and count) corresponding to the column order (and count) in the data table.
        Returns:
        true if the row was updated succesfully, false otherwise.

      • deleteRowFromData

        protected void deleteRowFromData(int rowNumber)
        Description copied from class: AbstractDataTable
        Delete the specified row from this table. This method should not check the input parameter for validity, and should perform no other tasks on the table or its associated data. This method is optional, and it need not be implemented (with anything more than a shell method), though in such a case, the deleteRow methods should be overridden to throw an UnsupportedOperationException.
        Specified by:
        deleteRowFromData in class AbstractDataTable
        Parameters:
        rowNumber - The (0-based) number of the row to delete.

This method is optional, and it need not be implemented (with anything more than a shell method), though in such a case, the deleteColumn methods should be overridden to throw an UnsupportedOperationException.
        Specified by:
        deleteColumnFromData in class AbstractDataTable
        Parameters:
        columnNumber - The (0-based) index of the column to delete.
